H0.text: Wood is a substance that is magnetic and conducts heat.

H1.text: Plastic is the substance that is magnetic and conducts heat.

H2.text: Iron is a substance that is magnetic and conducts heat.

H3.text: Paper is a substance that is magnetic and conducts heat.

A4.text: Impurities, lattice defects, or grain and particle boundaries can 'pin' the domains in the new positions, so that the effect persists even after the external field is removed â€“ thus turning the iron object into a (permanent) magnet.

A5.text: This effect is exploited in devices that need to channel magnetic fields to fulfill design function, such as electrical transformers, magnetic recording heads, and electric motors.
